Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: My phone buzzes with a frantic call from Jamie—her voice is shaky, and she tells me her car has broken down on the highway. It’s late, and she’s alone, scared, and needs me to come get her right away. I grab my keys, heart pounding, already halfway out the door. Then, another notification pops up: the activist group I’m part of is about to send a crucial petition to our state senator, and this is the last chance to add my signature. We’ve been working on this campaign for weeks, and my name on that list could make a difference. I freeze, torn. Jamie is counting on me to be there for her, to show up when she needs a friend most. But the group is counting on me too, to stand up for what we believe in and not let this moment slip by. My hands shake as I stare at my phone, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, knowing I can’t give both what they need from me right now.
